department.ch: 工業管理研究所碩士班

goal.ch:
"This course is to prepare students in Institute of Industrial Management (IM) for the research in the area of planning and scheduling. A student who has taken this course will be able to read scheduling literature, design the algorithms for solving the problems, and analyze the performance of the solving procedure. The content of this course is limited to the deterministic scheduling which accounts for only half of the textbook. Namely, the content regarding stochastic scheduling will not be covered in this course. Some typical scheduling problems in the environment of single machine, parallel machines, flow shop and job shop will be used to deliver the theory or concept in designing and analyzing the solving procedure/algorithm. General-purpose procedures such as Simulated Annealing, Tabu-Search and Genetic Algorithms will be introduced as well.
This course will be lectured in English only when any foreign student from the Institute of Industrial Management register in the class. Homework assignment is usually due in one week after the announcement; each student also needs to take lab section (IA5054)."

Term project is required for this class and it is accounted for 20% of term grade. Each student is asked to research into a planning and scheduling problem and is required to turn in a term paper. Late work will not be accepted. Term paper should not be longer than four pages, not including cover page, table-of-content page, reference list and abstract page.
The guidance for researching into your topic:
1. What is your scheduling problem? Any academic/practical motivation for you to choose this topic?
2. Process of searching for related papers?
3. Positioning - by comparing your scheduling problem with those related papers:
a. Problem definition/motivation/research objective: Comment on definition/motivation/research objective in the related papers in light of your scheduling problem.
b. Solving procedures: Comment on the solving procedures in each of related papers and, after that, point out the possible direction of the solving procedure which may be appropriate for your scheduling problem.
c. Validation and evaluation: Comment on the validation and evaluation which are conducted in each of related papers and point out the possible validation and evaluation you may use for your research problem.
d. Academic contribution: Point out the academic contribution of each paper you collect.
e. What are possible further research directions? Why are they possible and important?"
